awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Automated Learning of Vehicle Energy Performance Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will research an internet-of-things (IoT) platform to automatically learn vehicle energy performance models (VEPMs). VEPMs are used to predict driving range and battery state of health in electric vehicles (EVs) on a per-vehicle, per-driver, per-route basis, and 8-10 times more accurately than today. It is estimated that over $150 billion will be invested in the electric vehicle ecosystem over the next decade. A significant obstacle hindering rapid EV adoption is range anxiety representing user concerns over the achievable distance and where/ when to charge the EV.  Range anxiety can be alleviated by providing EV drivers with contextual intelligence on their realistic driving range and recommended charging strategy, based on travel plans, driving behavior and vehicle model. Increasing EV adoption by consumers reduces transportation system fossil fuel consumption and emissions. As part of this effort, a cloud application programming interface (API) will deliver predictions based on the learned VEPMs; this will also enable energy-aware applications such as eco-routing, eco-cruising, eco-powertrain control, and planning of charging stops, among others, both at the individual vehicle and at the fleet level. Energy-aware applications can increase the overall energy efficiency of electrified fleets.

The intellectual merit of this project is to advance an IoT architecture to automatically learn VEPMs from real-time vehicle sensor telemetry and other data, such as maps and route topography. The plan is divided into three integrated goals: (1) the building of an IoT framework leveraging physics principles to capture the vehicle motion and powertrain efficiencies, as well as data-driven approaches to capture human factors, and uncertainty in maps and measurements, (2) efforts to address scalability and generalization of the learning in geographical areas with limited data and reduced expert supervision, and (3) the experimental validation of the platform on real-world driving data collected in a set of representative conditions. Statistical learning theory will be merged with predictive control theory using a mix of physics-based and data-driven models in the learning process. Scalability and accuracy will be attained by updating models in real-time using data and sharing models among vehicles of the same manufacturer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Phase I project focused on an IoT platform to automatically learn models of electrified vehicle energy performance. Such models capture how electrified vehicles take energy from the grid, how they use it when operating on the road network, and how these behaviors change over time. These models have many applications, including: prediction of energy consumption on a given route; prediction of charging time at a certain charging station given current and desired battery state of charge; real-time estimation of the vehicle load; optimization of route and charging stops; control of vehicle subsystems such as air conditioning, battery thermal management, hybrid powertrains. In this project, AV-Connect developed a platform that ingests sensor telemetry from the vehicle CAN bus and GPS, as well as other data sources (including traffic and weather forecasts and maps), and automatically learns and validates models of vehicle energy performance.

The project focused on electrified vehicles for multiple reasons. Most automakers have undertaken large efforts to electrify their fleets and are concurrently redesigning their vehicles? hardware and software architectures, opening opportunities to introduce new solutions. Another reason is that users have very different experiences when driving internal combustion engine vehicles and Electric Vehicles (EVs). This gap is due to vehicle limitations such as range, charging speed, cost of the battery, as well as structural limitations such as limited charging infrastructure. Range anxiety is a frequently mentioned reason for hesitancy in EV adoption, and it is clearly related to all the factors mentioned before; while range anxiety emphasizes the driving range aspect of the problem, a more general statement of the problem may include both battery constraints and charging infrastructure constraints. Battery constraints are mainly due to limited power density (available power per unit mass) and energy density (energy stored per unit mass) of currently available batteries; despite the great progress done recently, (relatively) low power density makes even the fastest chargers slower than refueling, and (relatively) low energy density requires larger, more expensive battery packs to store the energy that fits in a fuel tank. Charging infrastructure needs time and investments to become capillary, and prospectively some management of charging demand, as more and more vehicles will take their energy from the electric grid.

In sum, an unprecedented number of EV models will be released in the next 5-10 years, and there are pain points for both automakers and drivers that can be addressed by innovative software solutions. The pain points are currently tackled separately, but they share a common background which this project addresses in an integrated, holistic framework. Specifically, the scope of this project is on learning (in an automated and scalable manner) models that capture vehicle energy usage, driving range, battery charging, and their degradation with time (particularly due to battery aging).

A key achievement of this project is the development of an IoT platform that automatically learns such models based on physics principles (vehicle motion, components efficiency) and data-driven approaches (human factors, policies, uncertainty modeling); key aspects of this platform are scalability, ease of deployment, and ability to reliably operate with minimal expert supervision. The resulting models predict the vehicle performance on a per-vehicle, per-driver, per-mission basis, and can feed model-based control and decision-making algorithms with predictions of provable accuracy.

Another key achievement of this project is the validation of the platform and its learned models on real-world driving data, collected in a set of representative conditions. At the same time of this Phase I project, AV-Connect has also executed Proof Of Concepts with a major automaker, gaining access to CAN and GPS data streams collected during a mileage accumulation program for several electrified vehicles (for a total of about 50,000 km in the second half of 2020 only). These data streams were ingested by the newly developed IoT platform, used to learn models and compare their accuracy versus the actual vehicle behavior. Specifically, the models were applied to four highly relevant prediction and estimation problems (driving range prediction, vehicle load estimation, charging time prediction, battery health estimation) to prove accuracy and relevance in the real world.

Overall, the data prove the technical merit of this project's approach, by showing the accuracy of the proposed modeling framework, and by demonstrating the complete pipeline in real world, from data collection to learning to prediction. The relevance of this technology was validated by interactions with automakers; the proof points included the accuracy seen in road trials, and the power of an integrated platform. Easily exploring measured data and predictions through a dashboard, visualizing predictions and their use for planning in a phone application, easily deploying new platform instances to the cloud, automatically managing model learning and validation with minimal expert intervention, and quickly developing new model-based predictors and estimators, are all valued by technical and R&D teams inside automakers.
